thread.title_full: London attack survivor speaks of the moment he thought his friends were killed

author: Simon Robb for Metro.co.uk
title: London attack survivor speaks of the moment he thought his friends were killed
text:
Owen Lambert was told he will have a permanent scar after the attack (Picture: SWNS) A teenager who was pictured being led away in a foil blanket after the Westminster terror attack has spoken of the moment he thought his friends had died. 
Owen Lambert, 18, had been on a university trip to Parliament and was sightseeing with four friends when Khalid Masood ploughed through dozens of pedestrians on Wednesday.
Medics ran out of hospital to help people injured in London terror attack He was hit by the speeding car and knocked to the ground, along with his friend Travis Frain, who was also struck by the Hyundai.
Owen, who is now at home recovering, said: ‘I saw blood on Travis’ neck and I said to him “You’re bleeding”.
‘But then he gestured to my head. I put my hand to my head and it was just red with blood. I realised it was my blood on Travis.
Owen was bandaged up and wrapped in foil before being taken to the hospital (Picture: Getty Images) Paramedics glued the wound together (Picture: SWNS) ‘It all happened so fast. I assume I was hit by the wing mirror.’
The student did not see the car before it flew up behind him and he was knocked to the ground, leaving him with a gaping head wound.
Marks and Spencer issues urgent recall over fears soup may be contaminated by chemicals Emergency services arrived on the scene and began to tend to the injured pedestrians, including Owen.
He said: ‘I heard somebody saying that people had gone over the bridge into the water. So at that point I thought my two other friends were dead.’
Owen said he didn’t realise the severity of the moment until he saw an armed police officer running towards Parliament, shouting ‘shots fired’.
Owen thought his friend was badly injured until he realised the blood was his (Picture: SWNS) ‘Combined with the fact that the car didn’t stop, it was on the pavement and I saw a policeman with a gun, I knew then it was much bigger than just an accident. It was chaos,’ he said.
Three teenagers arrested after baby girl dies in hospital ‘Travis was sitting across from me clutching his arm, lying with his legs out. I asked my friend Harmen Van Arragon to get some tissues out of my bag to stem the blood but he was shaking and said he couldn’t move his hand.’
Owen spoke on the phone to mum Sharon, who was frantic with worry, as he was taken to a nearby hotel away from the scene of devastation.
A young paramedic tended to him, he said: ‘She was trying to help everybody else and was lovely. But she was visibly shaken herself. All the hotel guests looked shocked too.’
Another member of the public treated at the scene (Picture: Getty Images) A photograph of Owen being led away from the scene in a foil blanket became a startling image of the largest terror attack to hit the capital in 12 years.
Stag caught using his antlers to raid garden bird-feeder and eat nuts He was taken to Chelsea and Westminster Hospital by ambulance where medics glued the 2.5cm head wound together.
‘The staff were incredibly upbeat, helpful and lovely caring people,’ he said.
‘I was just trying to keep my spirits up. I wasn’t in any pain at the time. The police were guarding my room which helped me feel safe.’
Floral tributes have been left on Westminster Bridge (Picture: Reuters) Fortunately, Owen suffered no internal injuries. His friend, Harmen, had a leg injury and needed a cast for his arm.
The pair were taken by ambulance to the hostel in King’s Cross where the other politics students from Edge Hill University were waiting.
Wife who cheated must stay in 'unhappy' marriage They were delighted to discover that the friends they had feared dead were alive and well, Owen said: ‘I was utterly relieved.’
The most seriously injured of the group, Travis, was recovering in King’s College Hospital and the pair kept in touch through social media.
‘I was very worried about him. We were all incredibly lucky to come out of it alive and in one piece,’ he added.
Owen was hit by Khalid Masood’s car in the attack (Picture: PA) More: UK Van driver repeatedly rams car after stealing fuel 
Three arrested in Manchester in connection with London terror attack 
Best friends of London terror attack victim played Queen songs to comfort him as he died 
Recovering at home in Morecambe, Lancashire, with mum and dad Greg, the teenager, who is studying politics and history, is still haunted by the events which unfolded on Wednesday afternoon.
But he said the kindness shown to him by paramedics and the police officers who took statements from him had made him more determined to make the world a better place.
Muslim woman branded a 'monster' for walking past Westminster attack victim speaks out He said: ‘What happened on Wednesday has made me realise that you have to treat everyone with kindness, tolerance and understanding.
‘That’s because of the overwhelming support I received from the emergency services and everybody who I came into contact with.
‘They were professional, helpful, really informative, kept me up to date with what was going on, and they had been up since 7.30am and had 12 hour shifts the next day. They deserve medals.’
